trans-unit.source: Create an FQDN for a VM in the Azure Portal | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create an FQDN for a VM in the Azure Portal | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a Fully Qualified Domain Name or FQDN for a Resource Manager based virtual machine in the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a Fully Qualified Domain Name or FQDN for a Resource Manager based virtual machine in the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: Create a Fully Qualified Domain Name in the Azure Preview Portal
trans-unit.target: Create a Fully Qualified Domain Name in the Azure Preview Portal

trans-unit.source: When you create a virtual machine in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) using the **Resource Manager** deployment model, the portal creates a public IP resource for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: When you create a virtual machine in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) using the **Resource Manager** deployment model, the portal creates a public IP resource for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: You can use this IP address to remotely access the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: You can use this IP address to remotely access the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: However, the portal does not create a [fully qualified domain name](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fully_qualified_domain_name) or FQDN, by default.
trans-unit.target: However, the portal does not create a [fully qualified domain name](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fully_qualified_domain_name) or FQDN, by default.

trans-unit.source: Since it would be easier to remember and use an FQDN instead of an IP address, this article demonstrates how you can add one to your virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Since it would be easier to remember and use an FQDN instead of an IP address, this article demonstrates how you can add one to your virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The article assumes that you have logged in to your subscription in the portal, and created a virtual machine with the available images, using the **Resource Manager**.
trans-unit.target: The article assumes that you have logged in to your subscription in the portal, and created a virtual machine with the available images, using the **Resource Manager**.

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps once your virtual machine starts running.
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps once your virtual machine starts running.

trans-unit.source: View the virtual machine settings on the portal and click on the Public IP address.
trans-unit.target: View the virtual machine settings on the portal and click on the Public IP address.

trans-unit.source: locate ip resource
trans-unit.target: locate ip resource

trans-unit.source: **Dissociate** the Public IP from the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: **Dissociate** the Public IP from the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Note that it does not yet show a domain name.
trans-unit.target: Note that it does not yet show a domain name.

trans-unit.source: After you click on the **Yes** button, it might take a few seconds before it completes the dissociation.
trans-unit.target: After you click on the **Yes** button, it might take a few seconds before it completes the dissociation.

trans-unit.source: dissociate ip resource
trans-unit.target: dissociate ip resource

trans-unit.source: We will associate this Public IP with the virtual machine after the following steps.
trans-unit.target: We will associate this Public IP with the virtual machine after the following steps.

trans-unit.source: If the Public IP is a _Dynamic Public IP_, then you will lose the IPV4 address and a new one will be assigned after the FQDN is configured.
trans-unit.target: If the Public IP is a _Dynamic Public IP_, then you will lose the IPV4 address and a new one will be assigned after the FQDN is configured.

trans-unit.source: Once the **Dissociate** button grays out, click the **All settings** section of the Public IP and open the **Configuration** tab.
trans-unit.target: Once the **Dissociate** button grays out, click the **All settings** section of the Public IP and open the **Configuration** tab.

trans-unit.source: Enter the desired DNS name label.
trans-unit.target: Enter the desired DNS name label.

trans-unit.source: **Save** this configuration.
trans-unit.target: **Save** this configuration.

trans-unit.source: enter dns name label
trans-unit.target: enter dns name label

trans-unit.source: Go back to the virtual machine blade in the portal and click the **All settings** for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Go back to the virtual machine blade in the portal and click the **All settings** for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Open the **Network interfaces** tab and click on the Network interface resource associated with this virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Open the **Network interfaces** tab and click on the Network interface resource associated with this virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: This will open the **Network interface** blade in the portal.
trans-unit.target: This will open the **Network interface** blade in the portal.

trans-unit.source: open network interface
trans-unit.target: open network interface

trans-unit.source: Note that the **Public IP address** field for the Network interface is blank.
trans-unit.target: Note that the **Public IP address** field for the Network interface is blank.

trans-unit.source: Click the **All settings** section for this Network interface and open the **IP addresses** tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the **All settings** section for this Network interface and open the **IP addresses** tab.

trans-unit.source: On the **IP addresses** blade, click **Enabled** for the **Public IP address** field.
trans-unit.target: On the **IP addresses** blade, click **Enabled** for the **Public IP address** field.

trans-unit.source: Select the **IP address Configure required settings** tab and select the default IP that you had dissociated earlier.
trans-unit.target: Select the **IP address Configure required settings** tab and select the default IP that you had dissociated earlier.

trans-unit.source: Click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: It might take a few moments to add back the IP resource.
trans-unit.target: It might take a few moments to add back the IP resource.

trans-unit.source: configure IP resource
trans-unit.target: configure IP resource

trans-unit.source: Close all other blades and go back to the **Virtual Machine** blade.
trans-unit.target: Close all other blades and go back to the **Virtual Machine** blade.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Public IP resource in the settings.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Public IP resource in the settings.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the Public IP blade now shows the desired FQDN as the **DNS name**.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the Public IP blade now shows the desired FQDN as the **DNS name**.

trans-unit.source: FQDN is created
trans-unit.target: FQDN is created

trans-unit.source: You can now connect remotely to the virtual machine using this DNS name.
trans-unit.target: You can now connect remotely to the virtual machine using this DNS name.

trans-unit.source: For example, use `SSH adminuser@testdnslabel.eastus.cloudapp.azure.com`, when connecting to a Linux virtual machine which has the fully qualified domain name of `testdnslabel.eastus.cloudapp.azure.com` and user name of `adminuser`.
trans-unit.target: For example, use `SSH adminuser@testdnslabel.eastus.cloudapp.azure.com`, when connecting to a Linux virtual machine which has the fully qualified domain name of `testdnslabel.eastus.cloudapp.azure.com` and user name of `adminuser`.
